data.title: Jean Gervaise (1616-1690)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Jean Gervaise born 1616 Souvigné, St-Michel, Touraine, France died 1690 Montréal, Canada, Nouvelle-France including ancestors + descendants + 3 photos + 6 genealogist comments + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

Descendants

Profile last modified 11 Jul 2024 | Created 12 Sep 2010

This page has been accessed 7,815 times.

2.3.1 Jean Gervaise

Biographie

Jean Gervaise a des origines françaises.

Jean Gervaise

Mariage entre Jean Gervaise et Anne Archambault

Le 3 février 1654 à Notre-Dame de Montréal, le père Claude Pijart de la Société de Jésus célébra le mariage entre Jean Gervaise, fils d'Urbain Gervaise et de Jeanne Hérissé (se lit Pebisé dans le texte original), de la paroisse de Sauvignay, évêché d'Angers, et Anne Archambault, fille de Jacques Archambault et de Françoise Toureau, de Lardilière, paroisse de Dompierre en Aunis, en présence de Paul de Chomedey, gouverneur du lieu, Jacques Archambault, Pierre Gadois, et plusieurs autres. Le prêtre précise sur le registre que le mariage d'Anne avec Michel Chauvin avait été annulé et qu'Anne pouvait donc se marier.[1]

Le 25 mars 1654, Jean Gervaise et Anne Archambault firent un contrat de mariage devant le notaire Lambert Closse.[2]

Enfants du mariage tous les actes sont à Notre-Dame de Montréal (Mtl) sauf 1, noté (orthographe originale)

+Marguerite Gervaise, née & bapt. 26 octobre 1654 Mtl; mariée avec Jean Baptiste Gadois 19 février 1669 Mtl

+Cunégonde Gervaise, née & bapt. 30 janvier 1657 Mtl; mariée avec Jean Baptiste Lefebvre dit St-Jean 14 janvier 1676 Mtl

+Jeanne Gervaise, baptisée 5 mai 1659 Mtl; mariée avec Jean Dupuys 17 janvier 1678 Mtl

Jean Gervaise, baptisé 13 avril 1661 Mtl; inhumé 18 décembre 1672 Mtl @ 12 ans

+Louis Gervaise, baptisé 24 novembre 1663 Mtl; marié avec Barbe Pigeon 25 novembre 1686 Mtl

+Nicolas Gervaise, baptisé 11 mai 1666 Mtl; marié avec Madeleine Peyet 27 juillet 1693 Pointe-aux-Trembles de Montréal (consanguinité notée)

+Charles Gervais, baptisé 18 novembre 1668 Mtl; marié avec Marie Boyer 29 octobre 1693 Mtl

+Cécile Gervaise, baptisée 17 septembre 1671 Mtl; mariée avec François Preudhomme 20 novembre 1684 Mtl

+Urbain Gervaise, baptisé 8 décembre 1673 Mtl; marié avec Marie Caron 1 octobre 1696 Mtl[3][4]

Recensement 1666 MONTRÉAL

Jean Gervaise, 55, habitant ; Anne Archambault, 45, sa femme ; Marguerite, 11 ; Cunégonde, 9 ; Jeanne, 6 ; Jean, 4 ; Louis, 2 ; Gilles de Rennes, 45, et Antoine de Serre, 22, domestiques engagés.[5][6]

Recensement 1667 ILE DE MONTRÉAL DE LA NOUVELLE-FRANCE

Jean Gervaise, 52 ; Anne Archambault, sa femme, 36 ; Marguerite, 13 ; Cunégonde, 11 ; Jeanne, 8 ; Jean, 6 ; Louis, 4 ; Nicolas, 1 ; domestiques : Antoine Lesueur, 20 ; Barthélemy Lemaistre, 32 ; 4 bestiaux, 30 arpents en valeur.[5]

Recensement 1681 HABITANTS DE LA VILLE DE MONTRÉAL

Jean Gervaise 60 ; Anne Archambault, sa femme, 50 ; enfants : Louis 18, Nicolas 16, Cécile 10, Urbain 8 ; 1 fusil ; 8 bêtes à cornes ; 70 arpents en valeur.[7]

Jean Gervaise est inhumé à Montréal (ND) le 12 mars 1690, l'acte lui donnant environ 76 ans.[8]

Biography

Jean Gervaise migrated from France to New France.

Jean Gervaise lived

in Canada, Nouvelle-France.

Birth

Jean Gervaise

Son of Urbain Gervaise and Jeanne Hérissé/Pebise

Baptême: 24 mars 1616

Paroisse/ville: Souvigné, St-Michel, Indre-et-Loire

Pays: France

Bapt./Source:

Baptême : 1616-03-24 st-michel de souvigne-sous-chateau (auj. souvigne), ev. tours, touraine (ar. tours, indre-et-loire) PRDH

Souvigné sous Chasateau en Anjou (Montréal, 1653: la grande recrue de Michel Langlois)

PAROISSE DE SAUVIGNAY, DIOCESE D'ANGERS, FRANCE (Marriage record in Drouin collection)

Marriage

On 3 February 1654 in Notre-Dame de Montréal, Father Claude Pijart of the Society of Jésus celebrated the marriage between Jean Gervaise, son of Urbain Gervaise and of Jeanne Hérissé (reads Pebisé in original text), of the parish of Sauvignay, diocese of Angers, and Anne Archambault, daughter of Jacques Archambault and of Françoise Toureau, from Lardilière, parish of Dompierre in Aunis, in the presence of Paul de Chomedey, governor of the place, Jacques Archambault, Pierre Gadois, and several others. The priest specifies on the record that Anne's marriage with Michel Chauvin had been annuled and that Anne could thus marry.[1]

On 25 March 1654, Jean Gervaise and Anne Archambault entered into a marriage contract before notary Lambert Closse.[2]

Children of the marriage all acts are in Notre-Dame de Montréal (Mtl) except 1, noted (original spelling)

+Marguerite Gervaise, born & bapt. 26 Oct 1654 Mtl; married Jean Baptiste Gadois 19 Feb 1669 Mtl

+Cunégonde Gervaise, born & bapt. 30 Jan 1657 Mtl; married Jean Baptiste Lefebvre dit St-Jean 14 Jan 1676 Mtl

+Jeanne Gervaise, bapt. 5 May 1659 Mtl; married Jean Dupuys 17 Jan 1678 Mtl

Jean Gervaise, bapt. 13 April 1661 Mtl; buried 18 Dec 1672 Mtl @ aged 12

+Louis Gervaise, bapt. 24 Nov 1663 Mtl; married Barbe Pigeon 25 Nov 1686 Mtl

+Nicolas Gervaise, bapt. 11 May 1666 Mtl; married Madeleine Peyet 27 Jul 1693 Pointe-aux-Trembles de Montréal (consanguinity noted)

+Charles Gervais, bapt. 18 Nov 1668 Mtl; married Marie Boyer 29 Oct 1693 Mtl

+Cécile Gervaise, bapt. 17 Sept 1671 Mtl; married François Preudhomme 20 Nov 1684 Mtl

+Urbain Gervaise, bapt. 8 Dec 1673 Mtl; married Marie Caron 1 Oct 1696 Mtl[3][4]

1666 Census MONTRÉAL

Jean Gervaise, 55, habitant ; Anne Archambault, 45, his wife ; Marguerite, 11 ; Cunégonde, 9 ; Jeanne, 6 ; Jean, 4 ; Louis, 2 ; Gilles de Rennes, 45, and Antoine de Serre, 22, contracted servants.[5][6]

1667 Census ILE DE MONTRÉAL DE LA NOUVELLE-FRANCE

Jean Gervaise, 52 ; Anne Archambault, hsi wife, 36 ; Marguerite, 13 ; Cunégonde, 11 ; Jeanne, 8 ; Jean, 6 ; Louis, 4 ; Nicolas, 1 ; servants : Antoine Lesueur, 20 ; Barthélemy Lemaistre, 32 ; 4 beasts, 30 arpents in value.[5]

1681 Census HABITANTS DE LA VILLE DE MONTRÉAL

Jean Gervaise 60 ; Anne Archambault, his wife, 50 ; children : Louis 18, Nicolas 16, Cécile 10, Urbain 8 ; 1 gun ; 8 horned beasts ; 70 arpents in value.[7]

Death

Jean Gervaise was buried in Montréal (ND) on 12 March 1690, the record giving him around 76 years of age.[8]

Occupation

Baker, Militia Capt, Commissioner at Notre Dame, Substitute Prosecutor, Procurer-fiscal Judge

Première mention au pays 1653

Occupation à l'arrivée Engagé de la recrue de 1653 (ct LaFousse, La Flèche, 30-04-1653)

Engagé le 9-4-1653 dans la compagnie de La Flèche par Chomedey de Maisonneuve faisant partie du contingent de la Grande Recrue de 1653, venu défendre Ville-Marie des attaques des Iroquois [9]

Arrivé le 16-11-1653

Substitut du procureur fiscal en 1672-1678

Maitre boulanger (R. Jetté)

Occupation: Boulanger, défricheur

Remarques: Liste des immigrants engagés de St-Nazaire, 1653 : Jean Gervaise (procureur fiscal, juge intérimaire, défricheur et boulanger) et François Hérissé (absent), nés à Souvigné-sous-Château, auj. Souvigné. Les actes suivants sont à Souvigné (St-Michel). Une soeur et un frère sont baptisés : Jeanne, le 12-08-1613 et René, le 17-01-1615.

Notes

re: Jean Gervaise & family from the Spickler & Rockwood Genealogy

Jean Gervaise

Arrived Ville-Marie fall of 1653. Baker, Militia Capt, Commissioner at Notre Dame, Substitute Prosecutor, Procurer-fiscal. Maisonneuve was Godfather and Marguerite Bourgeoys Godmother to Marguerite their first born.

The following from Our French-Canadian Ancestors by Laforest:

The first man to bear the name Jean Gervais received his title of nobility, complete with coat of arms through a commission granted on 7 Jan 1441, by the Duke of Brittany, in the parish of Mauron, Bishopric of Saint-Malo, in France.

Two centuries later, about 1621, another Jean Gervaise was born at Sauvigne-sous-Chasteau, in the Parish of Saint-Genevieve, Diocese of Angers, in Anjou, Province of Touraine. His father was Urbain and his mother was Jeanne Pebise. Jean received an education, including some knowledge of jurisprudence. As a more practical matter, he also learned how to be a baker. Both of these talents would serve him well in his life to come.

On 30 April 1653 we find Jean at Saint-Nazaire being recruited for service in Canada by none other than the Governor of La Societe de Notre-Dame de Montreal, Paul de Chomedey, Sieur de Maisonneuve. Among others signing up for this draft we may read the names of Pierre Godin dit Chatillon, Louis Guertin dit le Sabotier, Pierre Hardy and Mathurin Langevin dit Lacroix.

Along with the rest of the group, Jean arrived at Ville-Marie in the fall of 1653 after a long, distressing and exhausting voyage. Immediately, he took up his duties as a part-time soldier in the defense of Montreal against Iroquois attack. When not standing guard duty, he kept busy baking and clearing land. Thus he would become the father of so many of the Gervaise families in North America

Within four months of his arrival, he married Anne Archambault, daughter of Jacques and of Francoise Tourault, who had come to the country with her parents in 1646. The following year she married Michel Chauvin, son of Gabriel and Marie Orouar. They had a baby who died in the Cradle but soon thereafter Anne would again be carrying another. No sooner was this child born, later named Charlotte, when Anne learned that she had married a bigamist who had a wife living in France. Needless to say, given the times, Chauvin was summarily dealt with and sent back to France. Maisonneuve had the marriage annulled and then he took some extraordinary measures to see that the child, to whom he was godfather, and her mother would be relieved of the social and pecuniary difficulties facing them. The governor permitted the assignment to Anne of the same wages formerly paid to her first husband "in order to raise and to feed little Charlotte for as long as Anne remained in the service of the Seigneurs."

It was under these circumstances that Jean and Anne were married. A few months after the marriage, Jean followed his father-in-law to Quebec (City). It seemed that Jacques could not make up his mind between the two towns, because he kept going back and forth; but not so Jean. His heart was in Montreal with his about-to-be-delivered wife. On 5 Oct 1654 we find him in the town founded by Champlain assisting at the double wedding ceremony of the two friends: Jean Decarie with Michelle Arthus; and Mathurin Langevin dit Lacroix with Marie Renaut. Some days later Jean was home for the birth of his daughter. Just as they had done for Charlotte, the governor acted as godfather while Marquerite Bourgeoys consented to be godmother to little Marquerite, christened on 26 Oct 1654

As a member of the contingent of 1653, Jean was entitled to a grant of land; this he received in March of 1655. It was 30 arpents on the Rue Saint-Joseph (later named Rue Saint-Sulpice). This grant in a prime location seemed to have put an end to his work as a land clearer and allowed him to concentrate on a new business: a merchant-baker. He was friends with Charles Lemoine and Jacques LeBer, so together they established a royal bakery in 1665. In addition to this business and his family life, he also concerned himself with the defense of the island. Ever since Feb of 1663, Jean had been a member of the Militia company of Saint-Famille, a soldier in the 8th squad

Among the facts written about Jean Gervaise, we are able to discern a strong energetic businessman possessing an inner sense of justice and respect for the law. In 1654 he did not hesitate to denounce the infamies of Jacques Linet, who was banished from Montreal.

In Nov 1657, when the Parish of Notre-Dame decided for the first time to assign some administrative responsibilities to three vestrymen. Jean Gervaise was elected along with Louis Prud`homme and Gilbert Barbier. In 1660 the archives mention him as "commissioned to receive fines."

The importance of Gervaise was easier to reckon after 1672. In March of that year, the Montrealers wanted him to become a trustee, a position which he declined to accept. However in August he received a commission, later registered on 25 Oct 1672, in which he was appointed a substitute Prosecutor. On 26 Sept 1673, another commission was added which stated that, when the official prosecutor, Charles d`Ailleboust, was absent on business, Jean Gervaise would be his replacement to render justice at Montreal.

Lets take a look at the role of "Procureur-fiscal" under the French regime: "Charged with exercising the public ministry of the Seigneurial Courts, the prosecutor in a Royal Court of Justice. Always alert to wrongdoing, he must take the initiative to bring before the judge, all persons who refuse to submit to the laws and regulations. In criminal cases, he is charged with the investigation. Another function of the prosecutor is to protect the interests of minors or of those absent from the seigneury; like when an individual dies or disappears, leaving infant minor children or assets, where no person has been charged with their protection. The prosecutor must immediately, in such cases, conduct an investigation so that the judge may determine the action to take, be it the appointment of a guardian, taking an inventory, or rendition of a bill." We may still learn some worthwhile things from the feudal regime!

When he was a judge in Montreal, he had occasion to affix his name to a memorable document which history brings to us. On 20 Oct 1676, the principal inhabitants of Ville-Marie assembled themselves under the leadership of Jean Gervaise and wrote a respectful petition in which, in five short articles, they formulated their suggestions as to the conduct of the merchants` fairs; on the sale of wood; on places for trade and also on the ban placed on their agent, Louis Chevalier, who found himself caught in the middle of a quarrel between Frontenac and Fenelon. There were 14 signatures in all. The petition was sent to Frontenac who received it very coldly. In order to stop the colonists from mixing in public affairs, on 23 Sept 1677, Frontenac forbade assembly or signature in common. Nevertheless, one year later, the same Monsieur de Frontenac assembled the citizens of Ville-Marie in order to find out how they managed the fur trade in their locality.

On 20 Dec 1683, our ancestor received a concession of 6 arpents of land toward the west, "alongside of the forest". Well up in his sixties, it is evidence of his activity.

Jean terminated his mission on this earth on 12 March 1690. His wife Anne, made her arrangements with her children concerning the disposition of assets and died on 30 July 1699. Both are buried in Montreal. Jean and Ann had 9 children, Tanquay tells us that later branches of the tree split into Gervais and Dupuis. The Gervais branch further divided into Gervaise, Beausejour, Harnois, Le Parisien, Rivard and Saint-Jean

Son Charles, like his father, was elected vestryman of Notre-Dame parish in 1701. His wife gave him 14 children, many of whom settled down in the counties of Berthier and Joliette.

Louis Gervaise, the son of Charles and Marie Boyer, wed Marie-Madeleine Langlois at Montreal in 1737. They went west to Detroit where they started a wood industry. His sawmill, located in the area of Port Huron, Mich., made him well known to everyone on both sides of the straits. After his death in 1763, his two sons returned to settle at Saint-Antoine-sur-Richelieu.
